CommonFields.Publication: 2008 Annual Report Conference on Electrical Insulation and Dielectric Phenomena
CommonFields.Title: Dielectric Integrity of High-Temperature Nanocomposites
Author: Travelpiece, A.M.
Nelson, J. K.
Schadler, L. S.
Schweickart, Daniel
CommonFields.Location: Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute, 110 8th Street, Troy, NY 12180, USA

Drying-Evaporation.Description: Nanoparticles were dried overnight in vacuum at approximately 190-1950C before mixing with polymer.

Mixing.Description: Composites were mixed in a DAC 150 FV-K SpeedMixerTM using a series of mixing/cooling steps with increasing RPM chosen to maximize dispersion in the final specimens.
Specimens were prepared by spin coating on copper substrates using a series of increasing RPM to maximize sample uniformity and solvent removal.

Heating.Description: Curing was a three-step process of increasing temperature, culminating in a high temperature curing step for maximum solvent removal. The lowest temperature steps were done under vacuum.

Scanning_Electron_Microscopy.Description: The processing was optimized to achieve excellent dispersion. This optimization was determined in part from scanning electron micrographs (SEM) and in part from the dielectric breakdown strength which decreased in composites with poor dispersion.

Differential_Scanning_Calorimetry.Description: Differential Scanning Calorimetry (DSC) was carried out on uncured resin. A drop of resin was placed in an aluminum hermetic pan and run through a sequence (in nitrogen) in order to mimic the curing cycle. The samples were then equilibrated to 40°C and ramped at O0°C/min to 350°C. Glass transition temperature was measured during the final ramp step.

Thermogravimetric_Analysis.Description: Thermogravimetric Analysis (TGA) was carried out on cured samples. Samples were prepared by scraping pieces off substrates and placing them in an alumina sample pan. Experiments were carried out to 900-950°C at a ramp rate of 20°C/min in air.
